column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Pass a Smog Test
#Text=Smog tests are done to reduce the amount of pollution cars add to the air .
#Text=Check with your local or state government to see if passing this test is required by law .
#Text=To improve your car 's odds of passing , take good care of it by repairing problems and changing out the oil .
#Text=On the day of the test , make sure the car is warmed up before getting to the facility .
#Text=A failed test means more repairs and more tests , but remember that it ultimately leads to cleaner , healthier air .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Fixing the Car
#Text=before the Test
#Text=Repair your car if it is n’t running correctly .
#Text=If you know your car needs repairs , get it fixed before taking a smog test .
#Text=Find an auto mechanic in your area to get a diagnostic test for your car .
#Text=Have them fix the issue or repair it yourself so you do n’t waste time and money on a failed smog test .
#Text=When the “ check engine ” light is lit on the dashboard , your car will usually fail the test .
#Text=Problems , such as a faulty oxygen sensor , become more serious and costly when left untreated .
#Text=Drive the car for at least a week after the battery is disconnected .
#Text=The battery is typically disconnected during repair work .
#Text=This resets the car ’s internal computer , which deletes the computer ’s diagnostic reports .
#Text=Drive the car for over the course of a week or 2 before the test .
#Text=The smog test technician will retrieve the diagnostic reports from the car ’s computer during the test .
#Text=Get an oil change if the car needs it .
#Text=An oil change is only needed if your car is near the next scheduled service .
#Text=Oil changes are typically recommended every or 6 months .
#Text=Old oil releases pollutants that can cause your car to fail the test .
#Text=If you have a technician do it , ask them to look for cracks in the car ’s hoses .
#Text=Check the engine ’s coolant level .
#Text=This is done by opening the car ’s hood and unscrewing the radiator cap. The fluid level should be near the top of the tube .
#Text=During the test , your car will stay in place and have less air flowing to cool it .
#Text=This fluid may be replaced during any repair work or oil change .
#Text=Get a pre-inspection to save money .
#Text=Pre-inspections are done at the same facilities as the official tests .
#Text=Ask the technicians to have a pre-inspection .
#Text=They ’ll give your car the official smog test , but the results wo n’t be reported to the government .
#Text=This is cheaper than the official test and should be done when you ’re unsure the car will pass it .
#Text=Taking the Smog Test
#Text=Inflate the car ’s tires before the test .
#Text=Many smog tests include a dynamometer test , which rotates your tires at high speeds .
#Text=Most gas stations have air pumps you can use to fill the tires .
#Text=Properly inflating the tires means less stress on the engine during the test since your car will be more stable .
#Text=Get a full tank of gas before going to the test .
#Text=Some dynamometer smog tests hold the car at an angle .
#Text=This exposes the fuel pump , which can mean a test failure due to more vapor in the fuel line .
#Text=Keep the tank as full as possible before going to the testing facility .
#Text=Avoid taking the test on a rainy day .
#Text=Wet tires can cause the car to slip off the dynamometer , leading to a false reading and failure .
#Text=The testing machines will dry your tires , so you can still complete the test on a rainy day .
#Text=However , it ’s better to avoid the risk and wait for better weather .
#Text=Use fuel additives to clean the fuel lines .
#Text=Fuel additives can be purchased at auto parts stores .
#Text=Follow the directions on the bottle to add the additives to the car ’s gas tank .
#Text=This is usually done during refueling .
#Text=Most gas is already treated with some additives .
#Text=However , extra additives can help your car pass the test .
#Text=Drive 20 minutes before the test .
#Text=If the testing facility is around the corner from your house , avoid going there immediately .
#Text=The drive will warm up your engine , ensuring that it ’s operating as efficiently as possible .
#Text=Take the test at a registered facility .
#Text=Go to your area or state government ’s website .
#Text=Certified stations are operated all over the area , so you most likely wo n’t have a problem finding one close to you .
#Text=Some of the stations may even be able to repair your car after the test .
#Text=For tests in California , for example , go to https://www.bar.ca.gov/pubwebquery/station/stationlist.aspx .
#Text=Take the test results to a repair shop if the car fails .
#Text=At the end of the test , the technician will give you a printout .
#Text=Hand the printout to a repair shop so the technicians there can diagnose your car and make any necessary repairs .
#Text=Retake the smog test until the car passes .
#Text=After a failed test , you ’ll usually be given a few weeks to fix the car without penalty .
#Text=Adjust the car as needed , then return to the testing facility .
#Text=Continue doing this until your car officially passes the test .
